abstract.p: Jim Towey letter says problem with end-of-life care is with health care system unaccustomed to listening, and more interested in curing than caring (S)

block.p: It is true that most people feel powerless to assert their rights to control decisions on end-of-life care (''Charting a Course of Comfort and Treatment''). But the problem isn't with advance directives as much as it is with a health care system unaccustomed to listening, and more interested in curing than caring.

It is true that most people feel powerless to assert their rights to control decisions on end-of-life care (''Charting a Course of Comfort and Treatment''). But the problem isn't with advance directives as much as it is with a health care system unaccustomed to listening, and more interested in curing than caring.

What is needed is the same kind of revolution that changed health care at the beginning of life, where mothers demanded a system that responded to their wishes and ceased treating childbirth as a medical event. The same kind of public militancy is needed so that palliative care is uniformly available, personal wishes are respected and followed and human dignity is protected.
